robustness of foundation audio models. Our findings aim to advance
understanding of the perceptual impact of audio production practices, with
implications for music cognition, performance, and affective computing.

AI.tldr: The study explores how foundation models can analyze the relationship between audio effects (FX) and emotional responses in music listening.
AI.motivation: Audio FX play a significant role in emotional responses to music, but their systematic impact on emotions is not fully understood.
AI.method: The researchers used probing methods to analyze embeddings from foundation models, investigating the connection between audio FX and estimated emotion.
AI.result: They identified complex, nonlinear relationships between different audio effects and emotional patterns, evaluating the robustness of deep learning-based audio models.
AI.conclusion: The findings enhance understanding of audio production's emotional impact, with implications for music cognition, performance, and affective computing.

title: Mitigating data replication in text-to-audio generative diffusion models through anti-memorization guidance
summary:
A persistent challenge in generative audio models is data replication, where
the model unintentionally generates parts of its training data during
inference. In this work, we address this issue in text-to-audio diffusion
models by exploring the use of anti-memorization strategies. We adopt
Anti-Memorization Guidance (AMG), a technique that modifies the sampling
process of pre-trained diffusion models to discourage memorization. Our study
explores three types of guidance within AMG, each designed to reduce
replication while preserving generation quality. We use Stable Audio Open as
our backbone, leveraging its fully open-source architecture and training
dataset. Our comprehensive experimental analysis suggests that AMG
significantly mitigates memorization in diffusion-based text-to-audio
generation without compromising audio fidelity or semantic alignment.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses data replication in text-to-audio diffusion models by implementing anti-memorization strategies, particularly Anti-Memorization Guidance (AMG). Results indicate reduced memorization without harming audio fidelity.
AI.motivation: Generative audio models struggle with unintended data replication from training datasets, necessitating strategies to ensure originality during inference.
AI.method: The researchers applied Anti-Memorization Guidance (AMG) with Stable Audio Open as the backbone, exploring three guidance types to prevent memorization during the sampling process.
AI.result: Experimental analyses revealed that AMG effectively reduces data replication in audio generation while maintaining high fidelity and semantic alignment.
AI.conclusion: Utilizing AMG in text-to-audio diffusion models is promising for maintaining original generative capabilities without replication issues.

title: Watermarking and Anomaly Detection in Machine Learning Models for LORA RF Fingerprinting
comment:
IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal
  Processing (ICASSP)
summary:
Radio frequency fingerprint identification (RFFI) distinguishes wireless
devices by the small variations in their analog circuits, avoiding heavy
cryptographic authentication. While deep learning on spectrograms improves
accuracy, models remain vulnerable to copying, tampering, and evasion. We
present a stronger RFFI system combining watermarking for ownership proof and
anomaly detection for spotting suspicious inputs. Using a ResNet-34 on log-Mel
spectrograms, we embed three watermarks: a simple trigger, an adversarially
trained trigger robust to noise and filtering, and a hidden gradient/weight
signature. A convolutional Variational Autoencoders (VAE) with Kullback-Leibler
(KL) warm-up and free-bits flags off-distribution queries. On the LoRa dataset,
our system achieves 94.6% accuracy, 98% watermark success, and 0.94 AUROC,
offering verifiable, tamper-resistant authentication.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes an enhanced Radio Frequency Fingerprint Identification (RFFI) system that integrates watermarking for ownership proof and anomaly detection for identifying suspicious inputs.
AI.motivation: Current RFFI systems are prone to threats like copying, tampering, and evasion, necessitating improved techniques for robust and secure authentication.
AI.method: The method involves using a ResNet-34 on log-Mel spectrograms for feature extraction, embedding three types of watermarks, and incorporating a convolutional Variational Autoencoder (VAE) for anomaly detection based on Kullback-Leibler warm-up and free-bits techniques.
AI.result: The proposed system achieves 94.6% identification accuracy, 98% watermark success rate, and 0.94 AUROC on the LoRa dataset, highlighting its efficiency in secure authentication.
AI.conclusion: The proposed RFFI system is robust against tampering, ensures ownership proof through watermarking, and enhances security by detecting off-distribution inputs, making it a secure authentication framework.

title: TITAN: A Trajectory-Informed Technique for Adaptive Parameter Freezing in Large-Scale VQE
comment:
Accepted by The Thirty-Ninth Annual Conference on Neural Information
  Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2025)
summary:
Variational quantum Eigensolver (VQE) is a leading candidate for harnessing
quantum computers to advance quantum chemistry and materials simulations, yet
its training efficiency deteriorates rapidly for large Hamiltonians. Two issues
underlie this bottleneck: (i) the no-cloning theorem imposes a linear growth in
circuit evaluations with the number of parameters per gradient step; and (ii)
deeper circuits encounter barren plateaus (BPs), leading to exponentially
increasing measurement overheads. To address these challenges, here we propose
a deep learning framework, dubbed Titan, which identifies and freezes inactive
parameters of a given ansatze at initialization for a specific class of
Hamiltonians, reducing the optimization overhead without sacrificing accuracy.
The motivation of Titan starts with our empirical findings that a subset of
parameters consistently has a negligible influence on training dynamics. Its
design combines a theoretically grounded data construction strategy, ensuring
each training example is informative and BP-resilient, with an adaptive neural
architecture that generalizes across ansatze of varying sizes. Across benchmark
transverse-field Ising models, Heisenberg models, and multiple molecule systems
up to 30 qubits, Titan achieves up to 3 times faster convergence and 40% to 60%
fewer circuit evaluations than state-of-the-art baselines, while matching or
surpassing their estimation accuracy. By proactively trimming parameter space,
Titan lowers hardware demands and offers a scalable path toward utilizing VQE
to advance practical quantum chemistry and materials science.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Titan, a deep learning framework that optimizes parameter selection in Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) to improve efficiency and accuracy, addressing key challenges like high circuit evaluations and barren plateaus.
AI.motivation: The motivation stems from two significant bottlenecks in VQE training: linear growth in circuit evaluations caused by the no-cloning theorem, and the occurrence of barren plateaus in deeper circuits, which lead to exponentially increasing measurement overhead. The authors observed that some parameters in the ansatze have minimal impact on training and sought to optimize around this finding.
AI.method: The authors design Titan to identify and freeze inactive parameters in the ansatze at initialization. This involves a data construction strategy that ensures training examples are BP-resilient, combined with an adaptive neural architecture capable of generalizing across different ansatze sizes.
AI.result: Titan achieves up to 3× faster convergence and reduces circuit evaluations by 40%-60% compared to leading baselines. This performance is demonstrated on transverse-field Ising models, Heisenberg models, and molecular systems up to 30 qubits, with no compromise on estimation accuracy.
AI.conclusion: By reducing parameter space early in the training process, Titan mitigates the hardware and computational challenges in VQE, offering an efficient and scalable approach for advancing quantum chemistry and materials science applications.

title: BabyHuBERT: Multilingual Self-Supervised Learning for Segmenting Speakers in Child-Centered Long-Form Recordings
summary:
Child-centered long-form recordings are essential for studying early language
development, but existing speech models trained on clean adult data perform
poorly due to acoustic and linguistic differences. We introduce BabyHuBERT, the
first self-supervised speech representation model trained on 13,000 hours of
multilingual child-centered long-form recordings spanning over 40 languages. We
evaluate BabyHuBERT on speaker segmentation, identifying when target children
speak versus female adults, male adults, or other children -- a fundamental
preprocessing step for analyzing naturalistic language experiences. BabyHuBERT
achieves F1-scores from 52.1% to 74.4% across six diverse datasets,
consistently outperforming W2V2-LL4300 (trained on English long-forms) and
standard HuBERT (trained on clean adult speech). Notable improvements include
13.2 absolute F1 points over HuBERT on Vanuatu and 15.9 points on Solomon
Islands corpora, demonstrating effectiveness on underrepresented languages. By
sharing code and models, BabyHuBERT serves as a foundation model for child
speech research, enabling fine-tuning on diverse downstream tasks.

AI.tldr: BabyHuBERT is a self-supervised speech model trained on 13,000 hours of child-centered recordings across 40+ languages, achieving superior performance in identifying child speakers.
AI.motivation: To address the poor performance of existing speech models on child-centered long-form recordings due to acoustic and linguistic differences.
AI.method: Developed BabyHuBERT, a self-supervised model trained on multilingual, child-centered recordings, and evaluated it against tasks like speaker segmentation across diverse datasets.
AI.result: BabyHuBERT achieved F1-scores of 52.1%-74.4% across datasets, significantly outperforming existing models like W2V2-LL4300 and standard HuBERT, particularly in underrepresented languages.
AI.conclusion: BabyHuBERT sets a new standard for child speech research by providing a robust foundation for analyzing multilingual child speech, with applications in diverse downstream tasks.

title: Undersampled Phase Retrieval with Image Priors
summary:
Phase retrieval seeks to recover a complex signal from amplitude-only
measurements, a challenging nonlinear inverse problem. Current theory and
algorithms often ignore signal priors. By contrast, we evaluate here a variety
of image priors in the context of severe undersampling with structured random
Fourier measurements. Our results show that those priors significantly improve
reconstruction, allowing accurate reconstruction even below the weak recovery
threshold.

AI.tldr: Explored using image priors to improve phase retrieval from severely undersampled Fourier measurements and showed it allows recovery below traditional thresholds.
AI.motivation: The research investigates how incorporating image priors can enhance phase retrieval, a nonlinear inverse problem, under conditions of severe undersampling.
AI.method: The study utilizes structured random Fourier measurements and evaluates various image priors to assess their impact on signal reconstruction.
AI.result: Image priors demonstrated significant improvements in reconstructing signals even below the weak recovery threshold.
AI.conclusion: Using image priors in phase retrieval can enable accurate signal reconstruction under challenging sampling conditions.

title: Physics-Informed GCN-LSTM Framework for Long-Term Forecasting of 2D and 3D Microstructure Evolution
summary:
This paper presents a physics-informed framework that integrates graph
convolutional networks (GCN) with long short-term memory (LSTM) architecture to
forecast microstructure evolution over long time horizons in both 2D and 3D
with remarkable performance across varied metrics. The proposed framework is
composition-aware, trained jointly on datasets with different compositions, and
operates in latent graph space, which enables the model to capture compositions
and morphological dynamics while remaining computationally efficient.
Compressing and encoding phase-field simulation data with convolutional
autoencoders and operating in Latent graph space facilitates efficient modeling
of microstructural evolution across composition, dimensions, and long-term
horizons. The framework captures the spatial and temporal patterns of evolving
microstructures while enabling long-range forecasting at reduced computational
cost after training.

AI.tldr: This paper integrates GCN and LSTM to efficiently forecast long-term 2D/3D microstructure evolution, leveraging latent space and achieving strong predictive performance.
AI.motivation: To develop a computationally efficient yet accurate method for forecasting long-term microstructure evolution across diverse compositions and dimensions.
AI.method: The framework combines GCN and LSTM in a physics-informed manner. Phase-field simulation data are compressed via convolutional autoencoders and processed in latent graph space.
AI.result: The model successfully captures spatial-temporal patterns, achieves robust long-range forecasts, and reduces computational costs.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach blends physical insight with advanced machine learning to provide efficient and accurate microstructural evolution forecasting tools.

title: Explicit Context-Driven Neural Acoustic Modeling for High-Fidelity RIR Generation
summary:
Realistic sound simulation plays a critical role in many applications. A key
element in sound simulation is the room impulse response (RIR), which
characterizes how sound propagates from a source to a listener within a given
space. Recent studies have applied neural implicit methods to learn RIR using
context information collected from the environment, such as scene images.
However, these approaches do not effectively leverage explicit geometric
information from the environment. To further exploit the potential of neural
implicit models with direct geometric features, we present Mesh-infused Neural
Acoustic Field (MiNAF), which queries a rough room mesh at given locations and
extracts distance distributions as an explicit representation of local context.
Our approach demonstrates that incorporating explicit local geometric features
can better guide the neural network in generating more accurate RIR
predictions. Through comparisons with conventional and state-of-the-art
baseline methods, we show that MiNAF performs competitively across various
evaluation metrics. Furthermore, we verify the robustness of MiNAF in datasets
with limited training samples, demonstrating an advance in high-fidelity sound
simulation.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MiNAF, a method that leverages room mesh geometry to enhance room impulse response (RIR) predictions for realistic sound simulation.
AI.motivation: Current methods for sound simulation struggle to incorporate the explicit geometric information of a space.
AI.method: The authors developed MiNAF, which uses room mesh queries to extract geometric context and guide neural networks for RIR prediction.
AI.result: MiNAF demonstrates competitive performance compared to traditional and advanced methods, even in datasets with limited training samples.
AI.conclusion: Explicit geometric features improve the fidelity and robustness of neural acoustic field models, advancing sound simulation techniques.

title: Real-Time Streaming Mel Vocoding with Generative Flow Matching

summary:
The task of Mel vocoding, i.e., the inversion of a Mel magnitude spectrogram
to an audio waveform, is still a key component in many text-to-speech (TTS)
systems today. Based on generative flow matching, our prior work on generative
STFT phase retrieval (DiffPhase), and the pseudoinverse operator of the Mel
filterbank, we develop MelFlow, a streaming-capable generative Mel vocoder for
speech sampled at 16 kHz with an algorithmic latency of only 32 ms and a total
latency of 48 ms. We show real-time streaming capability at this latency not
only in theory, but in practice on a consumer laptop GPU. Furthermore, we show
that our model achieves substantially better PESQ and SI-SDR values compared to
well-established not streaming-capable baselines for Mel vocoding including
HiFi-GAN.

AI.tldr: MelFlow offers a streaming-capable generative Mel vocoder for text-to-speech systems with low latency and superior audio quality compared to baseline models.
AI.motivation: To improve the efficiency and audio quality of Mel vocoding in text-to-speech systems while enabling real-time streaming capabilities.
AI.method: Based on generative flow matching and leveraging prior advancements like DiffPhase and pseudoinverse operators for Mel filterbanks, the authors developed MelFlow, achieving low latency in practical applications.
AI.result: MelFlow demonstrates real-time streaming capability on consumer hardware, achieving superior audio quality metrics such as PESQ and SI-SDR when compared to established baselines like HiFi-GAN.
AI.conclusion: MelFlow sets a new standard for generative Mel vocoding by combining low algorithmic latency, practical streaming capability, and high-quality audio output, making it a significant advancement in TTS technologies.

title: Shedding Light on Dark Matter at the LHC with Machine Learning
summary:
We investigate a WIMP dark matter (DM) candidate in the form of a
singlino-dominated lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP) within the
$Z_3$-symmetric Next-to-Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model. This framework
gives rise to regions of parameter space where DM is obtained via
co-annihilation with nearby higgsino-like electroweakinos and DM direct
detection~signals are suppressed, the so-called ``blind spots". On the other
hand, collider signatures remain promising due to enhanced radiative decay
modes of higgsinos into the singlino-dominated LSP and a photon, rather than
into leptons or hadrons. This motivates searches for radiatively decaying
neutralinos, however, these signals face substantial background challenges, as
the decay products are typically soft due to the small mass-splits ($\Delta m$)
between the LSP and the higgsino-like coannihilation partners. We apply a
data-driven Machine Learning (ML) analysis that improves sensitivity to these
subtle signals, offering a powerful complement to traditional search strategies
to discover a new physics scenario. Using an LHC integrated luminosity of
$100~\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ at $14~\mathrm{TeV}$, the method achieves a $5\sigma$
discovery reach for higgsino masses up to $225~\mathrm{GeV}$ with $\Delta
m\!\lesssim\!12~\mathrm{GeV}$, and a $2\sigma$ exclusion up to
$285~\mathrm{GeV}$ with $\Delta m\!\lesssim\!20~\mathrm{GeV}$. These results
highlight the power of collider searches to probe DM candidates that remain
hidden from current direct detection experiments, and provide a motivation for
a search by the LHC collaborations using ML methods.

AI.tldr: The paper explores a singlino-dominated WIMP dark matter candidate within the $Z_3$-symmetric NMSSM, focusing on collider signatures, co-annihilation, and suppressed direct detection signals. Machine Learning methods improve signal sensitivity at the LHC.
AI.motivation: To investigate dark matter scenarios that evade detection in traditional experiments and propose collider-based methodologies using Machine Learning for discovery.
AI.method: A machine learning-based analysis is applied to enhance sensitivity to radiative decay signatures of the singlino-dominated LSP at the LHC.
AI.result: With 100 fb^-1 luminosity at 14 TeV, the ML method achieves a 5σ discovery for higgsino masses up to 225 GeV (∆m < 12 GeV), and a 2σ exclusion up to 285 GeV (∆m < 20 GeV).
AI.conclusion: Collider searches, aided by ML techniques, can effectively probe hidden DM candidates, motivating LHC collaborations to adopt these novel methods for discovery.
